lines.text: Yeah. That sounds about right.
Ugh. Fine.
Is that enough? Are we done? We kn-know what happened.
The robber burst in, the dead guy started a fire, the robber sh-shot him, and statue man messed up at magic so bad that everyone died.
You think that’ll satisfy the Chief, Leo?
...Hrm.
I mean, it all checks out… I can’t think of a reason not to write this up and turn it in.
Wait, hold on a second.
I don’t think our explanation actually holds up, here, now that I think about it!
That fire tripped the alarm at 2:35- 25 minutes <c=#FF00FF>after</c> the gunshot.
Could the fire really have started before the wizard got shot?
It could just be that it took that long to get big enough to trip the smoke detector, but… that’d be awfully convenient.
And- and another thing! What about all that stuff you wouldn’t let me touch?
What about all that stuff?
Like, the bathtub with the curtain over it! Or the other pages of that book on the table!
We’re just going to let those things be a mystery?
I’m afraid we can’t disturb the crime scene without… without probable cause to link the specifics to the crime.
Wh- how are they not linked?
You never proved they were.
Well- they- they’re related to some crime, right? The spellbook on the table is proof that they were illegally practicing magic!
...Hm. Well...
I- I! I’m afraid we don’t have a w-warrant to investigate arcane misdemeanors. We only have a warrant to investigate the violent incident.
So just- go home. Weren’t you the one complaining about having to bother with this in the first place?
...Or do you just want to look at that spellbook so you can peek at its magic?
Hey, shut up! I’m completely clean, got it?
I’m not gonna violate my parole in front of two cops, anyway!
(...at least, not in a way they can see, heheh.)
Hm. Why should we trust you?
Why should you trust me not to read spellbooks in front of-
Waaaaaait a minute.
You figure something out, Seeker?
No, %THEY% didn’t. It- it doesn’t matter.
I’m not allowed to turn the pages of that spellbook because we don’t have a warrant, right?
A-absolutely. Don’t you dare go and touch that thing…!
...Wait a minute. Seeker, you…?
Just to be clear, I’m not allowed to flip through spellbooks, unless I have a good reason to think they’re connected to the crime?
Yes, you-
...W-wait!
Iiiiiiiinteresting.
So when I went over to the bookshelf and went through those <c=#FF00FF>other</c> spellbooks, I was breaking the rules, right?
...Yes! You were!
Uh, Leo! Arrest %THEM%!
I don’t think I’m about to do that, actually.
Y-you…!
It just seems pretty funny to me that you didn’t have anything to say, when I was checking out those books.
You sure were quick to remind me of the rules, except when those rules meant we couldn’t figure out our easy little explanation, here…
Wait, Seeker. Are you accusin’ Opal of…
Obstruction of justice? Something like that?
Wh- I- that’s impossible! Th-this is none of your b-business, anyway…!
Like, maybe she knows something about this case that she doesn’t want us to know?
Leo, my man- you wouldn’t happen to have arrived on the scene <c=#FF00FF>after</c> our forensics expert, would you?
...That’s-
-Meaningless! It’s meaningless! I didn’t touch anything, besides checking the bodies! Why would I want to do that?!
<f=OpenDyslexicSmall>Because you’re a jealous harpy who wants to see my career go up in flames?</f>
Wh-what was that?! What did you mutter, just then?!
Nothing. Don’t worry about it.
Anyway, I’m certainly not going to just believe Seeker’s claims. %THEYRE% a loose cannon.
O-oh? Um. Good.
Hey, boss, what’s the big idea?
...but %THEYRE% making a serious accusation. I think it might be worth lookin’ into.
I might not be authorized to open up new magic cases…
W-wait…!
But I’ve got the authority to perform an internal investigation on subordinate personnel.
And it looks like a bunch of things in this room are all… materially relevant to the investigation, or what have you.
This is… this is unfounded! It’s- it probably counts as harassment! I’m going to go to HR!
If you like. Have fun with that.
Seeker, I’ve just got one question for you this time:
Is there any proof that the story Dr. Whydah wants us to believe <c=#FF00FF>can’t possibly be true?</c>
You can investigate anything in this room, in as much detail as you want, now.
